title: MP01-18 THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF NEOADJUVANT CHEMOTHERAPY ON PATIENTS UNDERGOING RADICAL CYSTECTOMY FOR NON-UROTHELIAL MUSCLE INVASIVE BLADDER CANCER
abstract: You have accessJournal of UrologyBladder Cancer: Epidemiology & Evaluation I1 Apr 2016MP01-18 THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF NEOADJUVANT CHEMOTHERAPY ON PATIENTS UNDERGOING RADICAL CYSTECTOMY FOR NON-UROTHELIAL MUSCLE INVASIVE BLADDER CANCER Francisco Gelpi-Hammerschmidt, Dayron Rodriguez, Ilker Tinay, Christopher Allard, Nawar Hanna, Steven Chang, Quoc-Dien Trinh, and Mark Preston Francisco Gelpi-HammerschmidtFrancisco Gelpi-Hammerschmidt , Dayron RodriguezDayron Rodriguez , Ilker TinayIlker Tinay , Christopher AllardChristopher Allard , Nawar HannaNawar Hanna , Steven ChangSteven Chang , Quoc-Dien TrinhQuoc-Dien Trinh , and Mark PrestonMark Preston View All Author Informationhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.juro.2016.02.1848AboutPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissionsReprints ShareFacebookTwitterLinked InEmail INTRODUCTION AND OBJECTIVES We evaluated the potential role of neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NC) in patients undergoing a radical cystectomy in the setting of muscle-invasive bladder cancer histologic variants (BCHV) utilizing a large oncology database. METHODS Using the National Cancer Data Base (1998 to 2012) we identified muscle invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) patients who received NC prior to undergoing a radical cystectomy and categorized them according to histologic variants at diagnosis. We excluded patients who received adjuvant or salvage chemotherapy. Median overall survival (OS) was calculated using the Kaplan-Meier method. Cox proportional hazards regression models, adjusting for comorbidities, were used to predict association of NC with overall mortality (OM). RESULTS The cohort included 40,165 patients who underwent a radical cystectomy for MIBC: 34,510 received no chemotherapy while 5,655 received NC. The percentages within each BCHV receiving NC are as follows: urothelial (14.3%), squamous cell carcinoma (6.1%), small cell (45.3%), micropapillary (24.7%), neuroendocrine (36.4%), signet-ring (10.1%), sarcomatoid (12%), and adenocarcinoma (7.53%). Improved overall survival after NC was noted for the squamous cell carcinoma, small cell, neuroendocrine, and sarcomatoid variants; while patients with micropapillary, signet-ring, and adenocarcinoma variants had a worst survival after undergoing NC (Table 1). On multivariable analysis predicting OM: urothelial (HR 0.86, p<0.001), neuroendocrine (HR 0.31, p=0.01), and sarcomatoid (HR 0.65, p=0.03) had an improved prognosis, while micropapillary (HR 1.90, p=0.022) had a worsened prognosis when NC was administered. CONCLUSIONS Limited data exists regarding the potential role of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in the setting of non-urothelial MIBC. Our data reveals the impact of NC varies widely among different BCHVs. Further studies are warranted to better understand how each of these variants responds to specific neoadjuvant protocols. © 2016FiguresReferencesRelatedDetails Volume 195Issue 4SApril 2016Page: e8 Advertisement Copyright & Permissions© 2016MetricsAuthor Information Francisco Gelpi-Hammerschmidt More articles by this author Dayron Rodriguez More articles by this author Ilker Tinay More articles by this author Christopher Allard More articles by this author Nawar Hanna More articles by this author Steven Chang More articles by this author Quoc-Dien Trinh More articles by this author Mark Preston More articles by this author Expand All Advertisement Advertisement PDF downloadLoading ...
